metadata.title: Inflammation induced by influenza virus impairs innate control of human pneumococcal 1 carriage 2

abstract.text: 22 Secondary bacterial pneumonia following influenza infection is a significant cause of mortality 23 worldwide. Upper respiratory tract pneumococcal carriage is important as both determinants of 24 disease and population transmission. The immunological mechanisms that contain pneumococcal 25 carriage are well-studied in mice but remain unclear in humans. Loss of this control of carriage 26 following influenza infection is associated with secondary bacterial pneumonia during seasonal and 27 pandemic outbreaks. We used a human type 6B pneumococcal challenge model to show that 28 carriage acquisition induces early degranulation of resident neutrophils and recruitment of 29 monocytes to the nose. Monocyte function associated with clearance of pneumococcal carriage.

30 Prior nasal infection with live attenuated influenza virus induced inflammation, impaired innate 31 function and altered genome-wide nasal gene responses to pneumococcal carriage. Levels of the 32 cytokine IP-10 promoted by viral infection at the time of pneumococcal encounter was positively 33 associated with bacterial density. These findings provide novel insights in nasal immunity to 34 pneumococcus and viral-bacterial interactions during co-infection.

35 Main 36 Pneumonia is a major global health problem; it kills more children under 5 years of age than any 37 other disease 1 . The burden of disease is aggravated by old age, chronic lung disease, 38 immunosupression and viral co-infection. Secondary pneumonia following pandemic and seasonal 39 influenza virus infection is a significant cause of mortality worldwide 2 . 40 Nasopharyngeal carriage of Streptococcus pneumoniae (Spn, pneumococcus) is common with 40-41 95% of infants and 10-25% of adults colonised at any time 3 . Carriage is important as the pre-42 requisite of infection 4 , the primary reservoir for transmission 5 and the predominant source of 43 immunising exposure and immunological boosting in both children and adults 6,7 .

body_text.text: 3 severity, as well as with within-household Spn transmission 5, [9] [10] [11] . The mechanisms and markers 47 associated with this pathogen synergy have been difficult to study in human subjects due to the 48 rapid nature of the disease.

One safe way to simulate influenza infection in the nose is using Live Attenuated Influenza Vaccine 50 (LAIV), consisting of cold-adapted influenza viruses. LAIV has been shown to affect the 51 subsequent susceptibility to Spn and to lead to increased carriage density in murine models of 52 infection and in vaccinated children 12, 13 . In a randomised controlled trial, we showed that LAIV 53 administration prior to Spn challenge led to 50% increase in Spn acquisition by molecular methods 54 as well as 10-fold increase in nasopharyngeal bacterial load 14 .

In murine models of pneumococcal carriage, Th17-dependent recruitment of neutrophils and . We collected a series of nasal micro-biopsies and nasal lining fluid throughout the study to 80 assess ongoing cellular and cytokine responses. Participants were grouped in those who did not 81 become colonized following Spn challenge (carriage-) and those who did (carriage+), as 82 determined by classical microbiology (Fig 1a) . To investigate whether LAIV-induced immune 83 responses were associated with a predisposition to pneumococcal carriage, we measured levels of 84 30 cytokines in nasal lining fluid (Fig 1b) . At day 0, directly prior to Spn inoculation, LAIV 85 significantly increased levels of twenty cytokines after multiple testing correction, including IP-10, 86 TNF-α, IL-10, IFN-and IL-15 (Fig 1b and Table S1 ). In contrast, the control group did not show 87 any significant increase in cytokine response at day 0. Following Spn inoculation, Spn carriage in 88 the absence of LAIV was associated with increased levels of EGF at day 2 (p = 0.023) and 89 decreased levels of IL-1RA at day 9 post Spn inoculation (p = 0.027) compared to baseline, neither 90 of which remained significant after multiple testing correction. No other cytokines, including IL-17A 91 or MCP-1, were significantly altered by carriage alone (Fig 1b) . 5 become carriers (2.4-fold increase, p = 0.0008) than in those who remained carriage-negative (1.5-98 fold increase, p = 0.051). Moreover, subjects with increased levels of IP-10 before inoculation 99 displayed higher pneumococcal density following Spn inoculation (Fig 1d) . This suggests that 100 differences in the response to influenza virus are associated with secondary susceptibility to Spn.

To test whether this was specific for LAIV infection, we measured IP-10 in nasal washes from an 102 independent cohort in which a subset of subjects had asymptomatic viral upper respiratory tract 103 infection before Spn inoculation. These comprised rhinovirus (n=12), coronavirus (n=5), respiratory 104 syncytial virus (n=2) and parainfluenzavirus (n=1) 29 . The predominant virus, rhinovirus, was 105 recently shown to associate with increased pneumococcal acquisition and transmission 30 . In these 106 virus-infected subjects, levels of IP-10 were increased (Fig S2) , and baseline IP-10 levels 107 correlated with increased pneumococcal density also in this second cohort (r = 0.32, p = 0.02, Fig   108   1e ). While the correlation was modest in this validation cohort suggesting that other host and 109 environmental factors are involved, this is the first time a biomarker predicting Spn density has 110 been identified.

In murine models, neutrophil recruitment after onset of carriage contributes to control of the 113 bacteria 15 . We observed pre-existent high levels of neutrophils in the human nose and 114 pneumococcal carriage did not lead to significant further recruitment of neutrophils (Fig S3a,b) . To 115 investigate whether luminal neutrophils were involved in the early control of carriage, we measured 116 myeloperoxidase (MPO) levels, a marker for neutrophil degranulation 31 , in nasal wash. Levels 117 were increased (2.2-fold, p < 0.05) at 2 days after challenge in control carriage+ but not carriage-118 individuals (Fig 2a) . This neutrophil activation was impaired in the LAIV group, who displayed high 119 carriage density during early carriage and had increased acquisition compared to controls.
Together, this suggests that neutrophil degranulation is important for the initial control of carriage.

LAIV administration from a subset of subjects. We confirmed that opsonophagocytic killing of Spn 124 by blood neutrophils was decreased following LAIV (Fig 2b, p < 0.05 ). This effect could be 125 mimicked by the addition of TNF-α, but not IP-10, to neutrophils from healthy donors in vitro, 126 decreasing killing capacity in a dose-dependent manner (Fig 2c,d) . Nanostring expression analysis 127 of 594 genes revealed 10 differentially expressed genes in blood neutrophils 3 days post LAIV 128 (Table S2) . Among those were MAP4K2 (3.2-fold increase, p=3.2x10 -5 ), which acts on the TNF-α 129 signal transduction pathway 33 , and TIGIT (3.6-fold increase, p=0.008, Fig 2e) . TIGIT expression 130 levels also negatively correlated with neutrophil killing capacity (r=-0.73, p=0.02, Fig 2f) . TIGIT is 131 an "immune checkpoint" protein, which has been described to promote Treg cell function 34 , but its 132 expression on neutrophils has not been previously appreciated. Incubation of whole blood with 133 recombinant TNF-α increased TIGIT levels on neutrophil surface within 30 minutes in a dose-134 dependent manner (Fig 2g) .

Indeed, for subjects in the control group with very low carriage densities, which were only 145 detectable by molecular methods, no monocyte recruitment was observed (Fig S4c) . This suggests 146 that a minimum Spn load is required for sensing and monocyte recruitment and that LAIV infection 147 interferes with this process. While MCP-1 was not significantly induced following Spn carriage, 148 levels correlated with numbers of monocytes at all timepoints ( Fig S5a) . Furthermore, stratification 7 of individuals showed that those with increased MCP-1 levels at day 2 post Spn inoculation exhibit 150 increased monocyte recruitment (Fig S5b) . Levels of IL-6, IFN-γ and TNF-α also correlated with 151 levels of monocytes at each time point, but stratification of individuals did not reveal a differential 152 recruitment of monocytes (Fig S5a,b) . In a second, independent cohort that did not receive any 153 vaccine, monocytes were increased at day 9 following Spn inoculation, which correlated with 154 increased MCP-1 levels in nasal fluid, validating these results (Table S3 and Fig S5c) . pneumococcal cytokine responses by re-challenge was absent (Fig 4a and Fig S6a) . The 162 production of the above five cytokines correlated with decreased density at day 29 post Spn 163 inoculation, suggesting these responses are involved in Spn clearance (Fig 4b) . To test whether 164 monocytes/macrophages were the source of these cytokines we compared the cytokine signature 165 from whole nasal cells with that from alveolar macrophages exposed to Spn in vitro (Fig 4c) .

Relative cytokine production highly correlated (r = 0.66, p < 0.0001) between the two cell 167 populations, suggesting that nasal monocytes/macrophages could be the source of these 168 cytokines. This is supported by the observation that in carriers with low carriage density (only 169 detectable by molecular methods), absence of monocyte recruitment associated with absent Spn- Table S4 ). Carriage without LAIV induced 834 and 176 differentially 8 expressed genes (DEG) at day 2 and day 9, respectively (Fig 5a) . These genes were enriched for 176 pathways associated with Gap junction trafficking and regulation (including GJA1, TJP1 and 177 multiple GJB) and degradation of the extracellular matrix (including COL17A1, COL12A1, LAMA3, 178 KLK7). In the carriage-group, a smaller number of DEG was observed (161 and 248 at day 2 and 179 day 9, respectively).

In the LAIV carriage+ group, 936 and 711 DEG were observed at day 2 and day 9, respectively. To further investigate these monocytes, we performed gene 213 set enrichment analysis on the Module M1 genes using list of genes from distinct monocyte 214 subsets (Fig 6c) 40 . These genes were enriched for classical CD14+CD16-monocytes (p = 215 0.00002) and not for other monocyte subsets. Moreover, this module was enriched for genes 216 related to "chemokine receptors bind chemokines" and "interferon α /β signalling" (Fig 6d) . Type I 217 interferon has been shown to be required for the clearance of pneumococcal carriage in murine 218 models 41 and these findings suggest that their activity in monocytes might be critical for this.

In addition, our findings that LAIV led to impaired blood neutrophil killing capacity and that the 246 addition of TNF-α, which was increased following LAIV, to neutrophils in vitro impaired their The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/347161 doi: bioRxiv preprint
We identified IP-10 as a marker for increased susceptibility to Spn and propose this should be

Our results support previous findings from murine models showing that MCP-1 signalling and 263 monocyte recruitment are key mediators of pneumococcal carriage clearance 16 . However, 264 contrary to key mechanisms described in murine models, we did not observe any production of IL-
17A or neutrophil recruitment to the nose following carriage or associated with carriage clearance 266 15-17 , underlining the importance of confirmation of murine findings by human data.

One limitation of this study is that only one pneumococcal serotype 6B isolate was used, future 268 studies using other isolates with a more or less invasive phenotype will be able to answer how 269 generalizable these findings across pneumococcal isolates are. Nonetheless, the observation that
In conclusion, this study highlighted the importance for innate immunity in the control of carriage 274 density and clearance of Spn, which was impaired by pre-existing viral infections (Fig S9) .

FIGREF0.text: 56 monocytes to the nasopharynx mediates immunological control and clearance 15-17 . Influenza virus 57 infection promotes Type I interferons which interfere with recruitment of these phagocytes, while 58 IFN-is postulated to impair phagocytosis by macrophages through downregulation of the 59 scavenger receptor MARCO 18-20 . However, the precise immune mechanisms and gene regulators 60 involved in the control and clearance of pneumococcal carriage in humans have not been revealed 61 21 . Moreover, how these mechanisms are altered during human influenza virus infection remains 62 largely unknown.

FIGREF1.text: In recent years, systems biology approaches have allowed for the identification of immune 64 mechanisms associated with protection from infectious diseases and with robust immune4 LAIV-induced inflammation leads to increased pneumococcal carriage density and 72 acquisition 73 In a double-blinded controlled randomized clinical trial, we administered LAIV (n=55) three days 74 prior to Spn inoculation (day 0). To verify the requisite topical application for an effect on 75 pneumococcal carriage, we administered tetravalent inactivated influenza vaccine (TIV) as a 76 control (n=62). LAIV infection led to transiently increased pneumococcal acquisition at day 2 77 (60.0% vs 40.3% by molecular methods in LAIV vs control groups, respectively) 14 . LAIV also 78increased Spn carriage density in the first 14 days following pneumococcal inoculation(Fig S1 and

FIGREF3.text: Pneumococcal carriage-induced monocytes recruitment to the nose is impaired by LAIV136 infection137Immunophenotyping revealed a significant recruitment of monocytes to the nose following

FIGREF4.text: 138 establishment of carriage(Fig 3a,b and Fig S4). Monocyte levels increased as early as 2 days 139 following Spn inoculation, peaked at 9 days (median 4.8x increase) and remained elevated 29 140 days post Spn inoculation. In contrast, there was no recruitment of CD3+ T cells to the nose(Fig 141 S4b). LAIV infection prior to pneumococcal carriage impaired the recruitment of monocytes to the 142 nose(Fig 3a,b). Moreover, peak pneumococcal density associated with increased monocyte 143 recruitment in the control group (r=0.51, p=0.02), but not the LAIV group (r=0.08, p=0.70; Fig 3c,d).

FIGREF5.text: Nasal responses associated with pneumococcal clearance are impaired by LAIV 156 To assess anti-pneumococcal responses induced by carriage, we collected nasal cells 29 days 157 post Spn inoculation and stimulated in vitro with heat-killed Spn and measured levels of 30 158 cytokines in supernatant. An increased production (FC > 2 and q < 0.05 to unstimulated control) of 159 TNF-α, MIP-1α, IL-10, IL-6 and GM-CSF upon restimulation was observed in the control carriage+

FIGREF10.text: Surprisingly, despite the high levels of inflammatory cytokines observed in the LAIV carriage-182 group, only a relatively small number of DEG were observed at days 2 and 9 (126 and 153, 183 respectively). DEG of carriage+ subjects receiving LAIV and DEG of carriage+ without LAIV 184 showed very little overlap with only 38 DEG at day 2 and 2 DEG at day 9 in common. Very little 185 overlap was also observed on the pathway level between these groups, indicating LAIV alters the 186 natural responses to pneumococcus (Fig 5b andTable S5). This could reflect transcriptome 187 kinetics, such as observed in altered differentiation and cellular activation, or changes in cell 188 migration to the nasal mucosa.

FIGREF11.text: LAIV carriage+ group showed an enrichment for genes in TLR3 signalling cascade, RIG-190 I/MDA5 mediated induction of IFN-alpha/beta pathways and IFN-gamma signalling, which is in 191 agreements with the induction of antiviral responses following LAIV vaccination 35 . Moreover, TLR4 192 signalling was also enriched in this group. The pneumococcal protein pneumolysin is sensed by 193 TLR4 36 and it is possible that the increased pneumococcal density following LAIV vaccination led 194 to increased pneumolysin sensing. O-linked glycosylation of mucins, which are used by Spn as a 195 carbohydrate source for growth 37 , was also enriched in the LAIV carriage+ group (including genes 196 ST3GAL4, GALNT7, GCNT3, B4GALT5). ST3GAL4 is a sialyl transferase and cleavage of sialic 197 acids by the influenza neuraminidase has previously been shown to promote pneumococcal 198 growth 38 . This finding supports a LAIV-mediated effect on pneumococcal growth through 199 alterations of host factors. Common genes and pathways between the LAIV-vaccinated and control 200 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF12.text: modules associated with recruitment of monocytes 204 To identify sets of co-expressed genes post LAIV and carriage, we ran our program CEMiTool on 205 the baseline-normalized data of LAIV and control groups, separately 39 . This modular expression 206 analysis revealed the genes that may act together or are similarly regulated during the immune 207 responses to carriage/infection.

FIGREF13.text: Genes in the control cohort were grouped into four co-expression modules, of which three were 209 significantly enriched for known Reactome pathways (Supp html file 1). Module M1 was enriched 210 in carriage+ at day 9 post Spn inoculation(Fig 6a). Levels of monocytes correlated with the 211 average fold change count in this module, suggesting that these genes reflect the infiltration of 212 monocytes (r = 0.61, p = 0.03,

FIGREF14.text: CXCL6 and its receptor CXCR2 were identified as hubs in this module M1 (Fig 6e and Supp 221 html file 1). CXCR2 engagement has been shown to induce attachment of monocytes to the 222 endothelial layer, initiating chemotaxis, which suggests this interaction could contribute to 223 monocyte recruitment 42 . Module M3 was enriched in genes related to "extracellular matrix224organization" and "collagen formation"(Fig S7).

FIGREF16.text: ISG15, OAS1, OASL, IFIT1-3, and IFITM1. Altogether, our findings reveal that a strong local 231 antiviral response is elicited in response to LAIV infection.

FIGREF17.text: addresses fundamental questions about the immune responses that control and clear 234 Spn carriage and how influenza infection can alter this control. By using for the first time a double 235 experimental human challenge model with LAIV and Spn, we revealed that Spn carriage led to a 236 quick degranulation of pre-existent nasal neutrophils in the human nose and recruitment of 237 monocytes, promoting bacterial clearance. LAIV infection impaired these immune responses 238 following carriage. LAIV is an attenuated influenza strain and wild-type influenza viruses might 239 have even more pronounced effects on the host response to pneumococcus. Carriage in the 240 absence of LAIV was associated with only limited inflammation, corroborating the view of Spn as a 241 commensal bacterium that can asymptomatically colonize healthy adults 43 . In contrast, robust pro-242 inflammatory cytokine responses were measured following LAIV at both the protein and gene 243 expression level. Altogether, these results provide explanation for our previous report that LAIV 244 increased acquisition of Spn and carriage density 14 .

FIGREF18.text: 247 activity, highlights their crucial roles in susceptibility to secondary bacterial infection 44 . The 248 association of TIGIT in this impaired neutrophil function following influenza infection warrants 249 further investigation as TIGIT-blocking therapeutics are currently being developed for cancer and 250 HIV treatment 45 .

FIGREF20.text: infections. Our data showed that individuals with higher levels of IP-10 prior to Spn 254 inoculation had higher bacterial density. In a recent study, children with pneumonia with viral and 255 bacterial (predominantly pneumococcal) co-infection had increased levels of IP-10 compared to 256 children with just viral or bacterial pneumonia, which associated with disease severity 46 . Murine 257 data suggests that IP-10 plays a direct role during pneumonia. Mice with genetic ablation of 258 CXCR3, the receptor for IP-10, CXCL9 and CXCL11, showed increased survival, decreased lung 259 inflammation and less invasion following infection, depending on pneumococcal inoculation strain 260 used 47 . Moreover, addition of exogenous IP-10 prior to infection of mice with influenza or RSV 261 increased pneumonia severity 48 .

FIGREF21.text: 270carriage density and duration declines in parallel for all serotypes following repeated exposure,271suggests that immunological control of newly-acquired Spn is mediated by similar mechanisms 272 independent of the colonizing serotype 49 .

FIGREF22.text: Tetra or FluMist Tetra, AstraZeneca, UK) or intramuscular Quadrivalent Inactivated 282 Influenza Vaccination (Fluarix Tetra, GlaxoSmithKline, UK) as described previously 14 . The control 283 group also received a nasal saline spray, while the LAIV group also received a intramuscular 284 saline injection. Three days post vaccination all subjects were inoculated with 80,000 CFU per 285 nostril of 6B type Spn as described 6,51 . Nasal microbiopsies (ASL Rhino-Pro © , Arlington Scientific) 286 and nasal lining fluid (Nasosorption™, Hunt Developments) samples were collected and stored at -287 80C as previously described 52 .

FIGREF23.text: double-blinded randomized clinical LAIV-EHPC trial was registered on EudraCT (Number

FIGREF24.text: 26) on 28 th April 2015 and ISRCTN (Number 16993271) on 2 nd Sep 2015 and was

FIGREF25.text: 291 co-sponsored by the Royal Liverpool University Hospital and the Liverpool School of Tropical 292 Medicine. Key eligibility criteria included: capacity to give informed consent, no 293 immunocompromised state or contact with susceptible individuals, no influenza vaccine or infection 294 in the last two years and not having taken part in EHPC studies in the past three years. The 295 primary endpoint was the occurrence of pneumococcal colonisation determined by the presence of 296 pneumococcus in nasal wash samples (NW) at any time point post inoculation up to and including 297 day 29, detected using classical microbiology or lytA qPCR as described 6,51,53 . In this study, 130 298 volunteers were inoculated with pneumococcus, giving an 80% power to identify a 50% increase in 299 carriage acquisition. Of 130 vaccinated volunteers, five were natural pneumococcal carriers (two in300LAIV arm and three in control arm) and were excluded from further analysis. Another 8 29), detected using classical microbiology, the area under the curve of 306 pneumococcal colonisation density following pneumococcal inoculation (days 2, 7, 9, 14 , 22 and 307 29), detected using classical microbiology or by molecular methods (lytA), and the immunological 308 mechanisms associated with altered susceptibility to pneumococcus following LAIV. The outcomes 309 reported in this manuscript were a priori included in the study protocol.

FIGREF28.text: CD66b-FITC (all Biolegend), CD3-APCCy7, CD14-PercpCy5.5 (BD Biosciences) and CD45-320 PACOrange (ThermoFisher). Whole blood was stained for 15 min at room temperature with TIGIT-321 PECy7 (Biolegend) and CD16-APC, followed by 2x 10 min incubation steps with FACSLysis buffer 322 (BD Biosciences) to remove erythrocytes. Samples were acquired on a LSRII flow cytometer (BD) 323 and analysed using Flowjo X (Treestar). Fluorescent minus one controls for each of the included 324 antibodies were used to validate results. For the LAIV and control cohorts, but not the additional 325 validation cohort(Fig S5C), 84/553 samples (15.2%) with less than 500 immune cells or 250 326 epithelial cells were excluded from further analysis.

FIGREF31.text: Luminex analysis of nasal lining fluid or stimulated nasal cells334Nasal cells collected in RPMI containing 1% penicillin/streptomycin/neomycin (ThermoFisher) and 335 10% heat-inactivated FBS (ThermoFisher) were incubated with 50ug/mL DNAse I (Sigma Aldrich) 336 at room temperature for 20 min and filtered over a 70um filter (ThermoFisher). Cells were spun 337 down at 440xg for 5 min, resuspended, counted and incubated at 250,000 cells/mL in 96-wells or 338 384-wells plates (ThermoFisher). Heat-killed Spn inoculation strain was added at a concentration 339 of 5 ng/mL of total protein (corresponding to 4.3x10^7 CFU/mL) and cells were incubated for 18 h.

FIGREF32.text: Bacterial protein concentration was measured by Bradford assay, using bovine serum albumin as 341 standard and titration experiments were performed to determine dose. Supernatant was collected 342 and stored at -80C until analysis. For nasosorption filters, cytokines were eluted from stored filters 343 using 100 uL of assay buffer (ThermoFisher) by centrifugation, then the eluate was cleared by 344 further centrifugation at 16,000g. Prior to analysis, samples were centrifuged for 10 min at 345 16,000xg to clear samples. These were acquired on a LX200 using a 30-plex magnetic human 346 Luminex cytokine kit (ThermoFisher) and analysed with xPonent3.1 software following 347 manufacturer's instructions. Samples were analysed in duplicates and nasosorption samples with 348 a CV > 25% were excluded.

FIGREF33.text: were collected in RNALater (ThermoFisher) at -80C until extraction. Extraction was 351 performed using the RNEasy micro kit (Qiagen) with on column DNA digestion. Extracted RNA 352 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF35.text: neutrophils were stored in RLT buffer (Qiagen) with 1% 2-mercaptoethanol (Sigma) 357 at -80C until RNA extraction as above. The single cell immunology v2 kit (Nanostring) was used 358 with 20 pre-amp cycles for all samples. Hybridized samples were prepared on a Prep Station and 359 scanned on a nCounter® MAX (Nanostring). Raw counts were analysed using DESeq2 using 360 internal normalization, which gave lower variance than normalizing to included housekeeping 361 genes. DEG were identified using a model matrix correcting for repeated individual measurements.

FIGREF36.text: Ensembl database 56,57 . The R/Bioconductor package DESeq2 was used to identify differentially 368 expressed genes among the samples, after removing absent features (zero counts in more than 369 75% of samples) 58 . Genes with an FDR value < 0.1 and an absolute fold change (FC) > 1.5 were 370 identified as differentially expressed.

FIGREF37.text: co-expression analysis, counts were normalized using log CPM and the log2 fold change was 373 calculated for each time point in a subject-wise manner. The co-expression analysis was 374 performed separately for each group (control and LAIV) using the CEMiTool package

FIGREF38.text: were performed randomised and blinded. Two-tailed statistical tests are used 382 throughout the study. When log-normalized data was not normally distributed, non-parametric tests 383 were performed and multiple correction testing (Benjamin-Hochberg) was applied for gene 384 expression and Luminex analysis.

FIGREF42.text: Pneumococcal density in the LAIV and Control cohorts. Mean and standard error of log-transformed carriage density [CFU/mL nasal wash] for carriage-positive volunteers (defined by detection of Spn at any timepoint) are shown for the Spn group (green, n = 14-24 samples per timepoint) and LAIV + Spn group (orange, n = 16-25). Density for samples with undetectable pneumococcal load was set at 0.1 CFU/mL nasal wash.

FIGREF43.text: LAIV-pneumococcus co-infection leads to excessive pro-inflammatory responses that associate with increased pneumococcal density and impaired monocyte recruitment. a) Experimental design of the study. LAIV = live attenuated influenza vaccine, Spn = Streptococcus pneumoniae. Analysed timepoints are indicated by black circles. b)

FIGREF44.text: Monocyte recruitment following pneumococcal colonization is impaired during LAIV coinfection. a) Median and interquartile range of nasal monocyte levels normalized to epithelial cell levels are shown per group. b) Representative dot plots showing monocytes for volunteers of the different groups at baseline (day -5) and day of maximum recruitment (day+9). Levels of maximum bacterial density are shown for the c) Control and d) LAIV group and correlated with the maximum monocyte recruitment. Individual subjects are shown and Spearman correlation analysis is shown. *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01 by Wilcoxon paired non-parametric test.

TABREF0.text: Neutrophil killing capacity was evaluated as previously described with minor modifications 54 .

Pneumococcus-specific responses are induced following colonization, which is impaired by LAIV co-infection. a) Whole nasal cells were collected 28 days post-inoculation and stimulated for 18 hours with heat-killed Spn for 48 subjects. Supernatant was collected and levels of 30 cytokines were measured by multiplex ELISA. The median and interquartile range for cytokines induced at least 2-fold in at least one condition are displayed. b) Correlations between cytokine production following Spn stimulation and pneumococcal density are shown. Spearman non-parametric correlation test results are shown per cytokine. c) The cytokine profile from alveolar macrophages (median for 6 volunteers shown) exposed to Spn for 18 hours was compared with that of stimulated whole nasal cells (median of carriage+ group shown). No reuse allowed without permission.The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/347161 doi: bioRxiv preprint Supplementary Figure 9 . Summary of immune mechanisms associating with control of Spn carriage and their disruption by LAIV. Carriage in the absence of influenza leads to quick degranulation of nasal neutrophils followed by a recruitment of monocytes to the nose, associating with the start of clearance. Influenza infection leads to inflammation, impairing this innate control of carriage.All rights reserved.
